Switzerland
Aug. I7, I969
Dear Debby:
I enclose a copy of a letter I have just written to a
Mr. William Leary, Jr., at San Diego State College. I
hope he comes out with a good book on CNAC.
Just writing the letter brings back a lot of old and
very happi memories.
My best wishes always,
Mrs. Harold M. Bixby
Topside
Bolton Landing
New York
U SA
arrived in Switzerland about
two
weeks ago,
from the Philippines,
on my fourth trip around the world
this year.
Since then, I have
spent
one week in Germany.
Now, I plan
to spend a few days with Anne in her
chalet overlooking the eastern end
of Lake Leman.
to
Then, I start
back
the United
States, possibly via
the Philippines and Hawaii.

Switzerland
Aug. 17, 1969
Dear Mr. Leary:
My apology for the lateness of this reply to your June 30th
letter.
I have
been
travelling almost constantly, and an
hopelessly behind with correspondence.
I regard Harold Bixby as one of the great men I have known,
both in relation to his ability and to his personal character.
In this respect, my experience has been similar to yours: I
have never met anyone who kanw him who did not have the greatest
respect and admiration for him.
You ask what personal
qualities Mr. Bixby
possessed.
I can
mention a few,
but they will be no more than indicative of the
to tal.
He had a face and a snile you trusted from the moment
you saw him, and the more you saw of him, the more he confirmed
your trust.
your true and a wonder and or eaty. And ne he fundamental
Bixby forsaw a future in aviation and, typically, he imple-
mented his vision by taking an active part in its development.
I can not tell you when his activities in aviation began; but
they were underway when I first flew into Lambert Field, at
St. Louis, in I923.
Bixby bought one of the first (if not the firet) Travelair
biplanes that was more than a reconditioned World War I trainer,
and he learned to fly it.
As you know, he was one of the major
backers of my flight to paris in the "Spirit of St. Louls."
He flew with me on a number of occasions, some of
connection
with the organization of "Transcontinental Air
Transport," in which he took an active part.
Later, he joined Pan American Airways, and quickly came
to be regarded as one of the company's ablest
officers.
In
this position, he took charge of pan American's interests in
China and, with his family, lived in that country for some
years.
As you know, he was outstandingly successful in this
effort.
Bixby was fascinated with China.
I am under the impression
that he regarded his years in
the Orient as among the most
enjoyable and worthwhile of his life.
I believe that in my previous letter I referred you to Mrs.
Bixby as a
source of more detailed information.
Her address is:
Mrs. Harold i. Bixby, Topside, Bolton Landing, New York.
With best wishes,
Area stant Prote beor or listory
san Diego State College
Charles A. Lindbergh
San Diego California.
